results.title: Steering, wheels, front and rear axles
results.creator_credit: United States. Army. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Automotive Operation and Maintenance”.
How to check for play in the steering wheel and the front end assembly; correct wheel run-out; make a test; test springs, axles and overall back-lash.

results.title: Steer 270
results.creator_credit: Brian Voce, Australia. Navy Office. Directorate of Public Relations and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: Follows a task force made up of the ships Perth, Derwent and Supply, of the Royal Australian Navy on a good will cruise of Mauritius Island, Mombasa, Karachi, Singapore, and Sydney.

results.title: Steelworker
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams, Australian National Film Board and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: a steelworker relates his impression of life centred around the blast furnace of the Port Kembla district. He recalls the processes involved in steel making, mentions the number of ‘new’ Australians employed at the works, and tells of the facilities for recreation, entertainment and modern living provided by the principal city of the are, Wollongong.

results.title: Steel: A Glimpse of BHP's Newcastle steel works
results.brief_description: A brief look at the BHP steel plant in Newcastle. The film looks first at the smelting process and then concentrates on the rolling and cutting of steel into different shapes.

results.title: Steel saga
results.creator_credit: Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Neville Bletcher
results.brief_description: Studies the growth and development of Port Kembla to 1960. Shows all phases of the production of steel and looks at the lives and activities of the workers who produce the steel. Narrated by David Low, Brian Henderson, Wynne Nelson.

results.title: Steel road across a continent
results.creator_credit: Fortune Film Productions, Commonwealth Railways and R.D. Hansen
results.brief_description: The Trans-Australia railway from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie stretches 1109 miles across the continent. Completed in 1917, the railway took 3500 men four and a half years to complete. Twenty year later, it was extended to Port Pirie. The film shows behind-the-scene servicing of the train and constant checking and maintenance of the entire length of track with specialised machinery designed for that purpose.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fortune Film Productions, Commonwealth Railways and R.D. Hansen

results.title: Steel rhythm
results.creator_credit: A V Curtice, Wallace Productions and Max Anderson
results.brief_description: A large steel works near Manchester is taken as an example of the continuous rhythm of production and the teamwork between scientists, planners and especially craftsmen, which make Britain one of the world’s chief exporters of fine steel. How particular types of steel are manufactured and milled to precise specification.

results.title: Steel and atomic energy
results.brief_description: The story of the part played by the steel industry in the British atomic energy power program. Shows the construction of three new production plants at Springfields, Capenhurst and Windscale. This use of atomic energy is only a beginning - its increasing use for other peaceful purposes will have beneficial and far-reaching effects on the future of mankind.

results.title: Steel (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People and Work”.
Looks at the effect that modernisation of the work processes has had on the industrial relations and the experience of work and its consequences for the traditional skills of steel making. Shot entirely at the BSC Anchor Plant at Scunthorpe, the largest and most up-to-date steel works in Europe, it concentrates on the steel workers themselves. A case study for the students of the sociology of work.

results.title: Steel 'n' skin
results.creator_credit: Arts Council of Great Britain and Steve Shaw
results.brief_description: The music and dance group Steel ‘n’ Skin represents a fusion of African and Caribbean cultures. Its director, Peter Blackman, explains the group’s real emphasis is on encouraging harmonious race relations. The group is shown on a ten-day tour of Merseyside (Liverpool) performing and encouraging community involvement in dance, African and Caribbean instrument making, Afro-Caribbean Cooking and making African clothes and prints.
